Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Planning Grant: Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The planned University of Tennessee, Knoxville site of the I/UCRC for Integrative Materials Joining for Energy Applications has the potential to allow accelerated development and deployment of hybrid material systems for energy applications and will be focused on the scale-up of proven laboratory developments relevant to automotive, aerospace, and energy applications. The research has the potential to enable scientific discoveries related to the thermo-mechanical-chemical properties of interfaces between these constituent materials to be achieved. Advanced in-situ and ex-situ characterization techniques will be applied to understand issues such as cyclic thermal and stress loading, residual stress development, and microstructural evolution. This new site plans to produce fundamental research at the crossroads of joining and additive manufacturing.

The focus of the planned site on joining and additive manufacturing of advanced materials is of central importance to the competitiveness of the automotive, aerospace, and energy sectors. The planned new site plans to work with Hardin Valley Elementary School (HVES) to recruit students for forming and mentoring independent FIRST LEGOfi League (FLL) team(s) as they tackle real-world engineering challenges. This interaction with elementary school children might be their first towards introducing and encouraging them to consider STEM choices in their future academic careers. Additionally, the proposed site of CIMJSEA will collaborate with non-profit organizations in Tennessee and the College of Engineering Office of Diversity Programs in order to foster interaction with underrepresented groups over a wide range of ages.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
A successful planning meeting was held in early December 2014.  It was determined that there was enough industrial support to go through with a full proposal to NSF and the full proposal was submitted to NSF in March 2015.  The proposal was positively reviewed and an award was received with a start date of September 1, 2015.  The intellectual merit of the center is related to accelerating the development and deployment of hybrid material systems that combine metals, ceramics, polymers, glasses and elastomers in different forms and shapes for a variety of industrial applications. The concept of hybrid materials has been demonstrated at the laboratory scale and activities of the newly established UTK site of the Center for Innovative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications (CIMJSEA) will focus on the scale-up for the development of components for a wide range of applications relevant to several key industries. Through the UTK site scientific discoveries will be made once the thermo-mechanical-chemical properties of interfaces between these constitutive materials are elucidated. Advanced in-situ and ex-situ characterization techniques will be leveraged to understand the roles of cyclic thermal and stress loading during joining processes on microstructural evolution, as well as, residual stress development. This new UTK site will complement existing CIMJSEA activities and bring the needed fundamental research at the crossroads of joining and additive manufacturing. Some of the research projects will explore the development of materials specifically tailored for additive manufacturing and will be translated into tangible technologies that can be implemented within the existing manufacturing ecosystem.

 

The broader impact of the activities within the planning grant of the proposed site included interactions with local industries and non-profit organizations in Tennessee. The planning grant activities also included an effort to encourage elementary and middle school students to get involved in STEM activities hopefully positioning them in the pipeline for choosing STEM majors in college and later becoming part of the STEM workforce. A FIRST LEGO League (FLL) team for children ages 9 to 16 was guided by the PI from the UTK site of CIMJSEA.  The young students were introduced to real-world engineering challenges by building LEGO-based robots to complete tasks on a thematic playing surface. The goal was to impart the basics of materials joining for making hybrid structures through Lego block constructions.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2015
Modified by: Claudia J Rawn
